Name: Auditing and Ethics
Description:
The purpose of the module is to equip students with the skills needed to manage ethical 
or moral dilemmas encountered effectively and legal and governance aspects in the 
workplace, the business environment and the work performed by an auditor. This module 
further introduces students to the basic principles of auditing and risk management. This 
module also integrates communication, presentation and business acumen skills needed 
by a student to excel in the corporate environment.

Name: Reticulation Design 3A
Description:
The purpose of Water Reticulation Design 3A is to introduce 
students to the fundamental concepts and principles in the 
design of water supply, stormwater and sewer reticulation 
systems. 
Content 
Introduction To Water Supply. Water Demand. Hydraulics of 
Water Distribution Systems. Water Reticulation Design. Water 
Storage Reservoirs. Stormwater Management. Best 
Management Practices. Urban Stormwater Design. Sanitation
Services in South Africa. Classification of Sewers. Sewage Flow 
Estimation. Principles of Sewer Design. Design of Sewage 
Systems.

Name: Transportation Engineering 3A
Description:
The purpose of Transportation Engineering 3A is to let the 
student understand the basic characteristics of the driver, the 
vehicle and the roadway and how these interact with each other. 
Traffic flow is important in developing and designing strategies 
for intersection control, rural highway and freeway segments. 
Content 
Characteristics of the Driver, the Pedestrian, the Vehicle and the 
road. Traffic Engineering Studies. Highway Safety. 
Fundamental Principles of Traffic Flow. Intersection Design. 
Intersection Control. Capacity and Level of Service for Highway 
Segments. Capacity and Level of Service for Signalized 
Intersections.

Name: Psycho-Social Aspects of Physical Activity
Description: The purpose of this module is to acquire the knowledge of various theories utilized within psychology and sociology, and how these theories and human behavior impact on physical activity. The module also focus on the wellness aspect and related physical activity performance.

Name: Therapeutic Recreation 1B
Description: The purpose of this module is to provide an overview of therapeutic recreation and its position within Biokinetics. Included in the module is the assessment and exercise prescription within therapeutic recreation for special populations and to inform on the processes to utilise to overcome barriers within this context.

Name: Anatomy 1
Description: The purpose of this module is to provide in-depth information regarding the different anatomical structures within the human body, including various systems, such as osteology, the nervous system, cardiovascular system, endocrine system, respiratory system, digestive system, urinary system and muscular system.

Name: Physiology 1
Description: The purpose of this module is to provide an overview of physiology, to discuss support and movement within the body, the various system that support control and regulation in the human body,to discuss fluids and transport thereof in the body, to delph deeper into the cardiovascular system and environmental exchanges taking place.

Name: Work Integrated Learning 1
Description: The purpose of this module is to learn practical clinical skills in the following field: Wellness, Orthopaedic Conditions, and Chronic Conditions. Learners should learn clinical skills in assessment techniques, intervention strategies and the re-assessment of patients.

Name: Biomechanics 2A
Description: The purpose of this module is for the learner to develop intellectual competencies and clinical skills in biomechanics and the assessment of health and fitness. The learner should be able to solve biomechanical problems, perform basic biomechanical analyses and be able to assess basic health and fitness components.

Name: Pathology and Pathophysiology
Description: The purpose of this module is to understand the basic terminology used in pathophysiology, to delph into the pathophysiology of various conditions/diseas e, and to identify the medications used to treat these conditions/diseas es.

Name: Perceptual Motor Learning and Control 2B
Description: The purpose of this module is to analyse motor development across the life span from infancy through older adulthood. Movement patterns and their developmental sequences, and the underlying mechanisms that are related to changes in these aspects will be studied. The processes of acquiring new skills and movement patterns and the correction of faulty movement patterns will be addressed. Learning will be facilitated with class discussions and examples; this will allow the learner to implement theory in real -life.

Name: Clinical Exercise Testing and Prescription 2
Description: The purpose of this module is for the learner to understand evidence-based practice and preparticipation screening. The learner should be able to conduct basic healthrelated and fitness-related evaluations on healthy individuals and special populations. The learner should also be able to interpret the tests and provide comprehensive feedback on the findings.

Name: Work Integrated Learning 2
Description: The purpose of this module is to learn practical clinical skills in the following fields of biokinetics: Wellness, Orthopaedic Conditions, and Chronic Conditions. Learners should learn clinical skills in assessment techniques, intervention strategies and the re-assessment of patients.

Name: Pharmacology 3B
Description: The purpose of this module is for learners to understand the basic principles of pharmacology, to discuss the different drug classes for the management of different conditions. The learner should also be able to explain the pharmacological effects of common medications on the physiological functions and the effects on exercise.

Name: Clinical Exercise Testing and Prescription 3
Description: The purpose of this module is for the learner to be able to discuss the pathophysiology of common chronic conditions, along with the performance of selected clinical exercise tests. The learner should also be able to interpret the findings, design appropriate rehabilitation programmes and discuss the special considerations for each of these conditions.

Name: Research Methodology
Description: TO BE UPDATED

Name: Work Integrated Learning 3
Description: The purpose of this module is to learn practical clinical skills in the following fields of biokinetics: Wellness, Orthopaedic Conditions, and Chronic Conditions. Learners should be able to perform screening, assessments and exercise programmes for apparently healthy individuals and low -risk to moderate -risk patients, and critically reflect on their experiences.

Name: Practice Management and Applied Ethics 4
Description: The purpose of this module is that learners should be able to understand the scope of practice of a biokineticist, discuss the different business models used in the South African context, and have a thorough understanding of the different health policies, health systems and structures related to biokinetics. The learner should be able to apply ethical conduct, understand the financial aspects of running a biokinetics practice and demonstrate the knowledge of basic management functions.

Name: Work Integrated Learning 4

Name: Management in Tourism and Hospitality 1A
Description:
The purpose of this module is to introduce students to the main themes and concepts 
of Business Management in a tourism/hospitality context. Students will understand the 
concepts of planning, organising, leading and controlling a tourism and hospitality 
enterprise within a local and global environment.

Name: Tourism Development 1A
Description: TO BE UPDATED

Name: Management in Tourism and Hospitality 1B
Description:
The purpose of this module is to introduce hospitality and tourism students to the field 
of general management. In addition, the module aims to develop a student who can 
clearly demonstrate a focused knowledge on the issues of the manager and the 
development of management theory as well as the functional areas of a business, 
namely operations management, human resource management, marketing 
management, financial management, and purchasing and supply management. In 
addition, this module aims to provide students with an overall understanding of the value 
chain and marketing management within the hospitality and tourism industry, so that 
they can interpret the process from sourcing to distributing and selling of products.

Name: Tourism Development 1B
Description:
The purpose of this module is to provide students with insight and knowledge to 
understand the different types of tourism impacts on economic, social and 
environmental aspects of various types of tourism attractions and destinations in the 
developing world.

Name: Management in Tourism and Hospitality 2A
Description:
The purpose of this module is to provide students with an overall basic understanding 
of key human resource management issues in the tourism and hospitality environment. 
Students will acquire a working understanding of human resource functions such as job 
analysis, recruitment and selection processes, induction, motivation, training and 
development, group-work, leadership and performance management.

Name: Tourism Development 2A
Description:
The purpose of this module is to provide students with knowledge about the effective
use of various levels and models of tourism planning in South Africa.

Name: Tourism Development 2B
Description:
The purpose of this module is to equip students with knowledge on ongoing debates on
sustainable and responsible principles.

Name: Financial Management in Tourism 2B
Description:
The purpose of this module is to equip students with the necessary knowledge in 
applying basic accounting and financial management principles for effective financial 
decision-making in a tourism and hospitality organisation. Students will receive 
guidance on how to manage the tourism/hospitality business in a sustainable financial 
way by the integration of foundational, practical and reflective competence.

Name: Events Management 3A
Description:
The purpose of this module is to provide students with an understanding and insight into
the events industry and the core functional areas of event management.

Name: Introduction to Tourism and Hospitality Research Methodology 3A
Description: TO BE UPDATED

Name: Enterprise Development 3B
Description:
The purpose of this module is to introduce students to the distinctive process of 
entrepreneurship. The module will clarify underpinning theoretical concepts with 
practical application examples.

Name: Tourism and Hospitality Research Project 3B
Description:
The purpose of this module is for students to complete field work, analyse and compile
a final research report based on their chosen research topic.

Name: Anatomy and Physiology 1
Description: The purpose of this module is to establish a sound introduction to anatomy and physiology, including human cells and tissue, surface anatomy and systems within the human body

Name: Clinical Diagnostics 3
Description: The purpose of this module is to provide the student with the relevant knowledge necessary for case taking, evaluation and management of a patient in a clinical setting.

Name: Basic Sciences: Physics 1A
Description: A grounding in physics is very important for the student. The physics learning outcomes are applied in a number of other areas in the qualification and also serve as a foundation for the students’ further development in their careers in the health sciences

Name: Basic Sciences: Chemistry
Description: The purpose of this module is to develop students’ understanding of the basic principles of chemistry to serve as a foundation for the students’ further development in their careers in the health sciences.

Name: Fire Search & Rescue
Description: The Fire Search and Rescue module provides the student with the necessary knowledge and skills to work as part of a team at incidents where oxygen deprived environments, smoke filled compartments or heat-filled compartments are present, and there are victims that require search and rescue.

Name: Physical Preparedness 2
Description: Medical Rescue work is by nature physically taxing and places demands on the rescuer, both in terms of strength and endurance. In order for an Emergency Care Practitioners to perform effectively and safely in the emergency medical and rescue environments they need to possess set minimum levels of physical strength and endurance. Rescue workers who are unfit are unable to perform as they should and this has a negative effect on the rescue operation as well as patient care. For this reason, all students who have registered for the Bachelor Degree in Emergency Medical Care programme at University of Johannesburg, were required to register for the physical preparedness module in each year of study. Students were required to partake in the on and off - campus training sessions and demonstrate that they were in acceptable physical condition. Students who failed to pass the Physical Preparedness modules were not eligible to register for any of the rescue modules, as these modules remained a prerequisite for registration and participation in the medical rescue components and related events within the B EMC programme.

Name: Physical Preparedness 3
Description: Medical Rescue work is by nature physically taxing and places demands on the rescuer, both in terms of strength and endurance. In order for an Emergency Care Practitioners to perform effectively and safely in the emergency medical and rescue environments they need to possess set minimum levels of physical strength and endurance. Rescue workers who are unfit are unable to perform as they should and this has a negative effect on the rescue operation as well as patient care. For this reason, all students who have registered for the Bachelor Degree in Emergency Medical Care programme at University of Johannesburg, were required to register for the physical preparedness module in each year of study. Students were required to partake in the on and off - campus training sessions and demonstrate that they were in acceptable physical condition. Students who failed to pass the Physical Preparedness modules were not eligible to register for any of the rescue modules, as these modules remained a prerequisite for registration and participation in the medical rescue components and related events within the B EMC programme.

Name: Marketing Communications 3A
Description:
The purpose of this module is to promote the integration of the skills and knowledge 
obtained in other marketing functions to develop a comprehensive integrated marketing 
communications plan. On a more practical level, the student will have attained the 
necessary experience to develop a practical communications plan within a variety of 
contexts to strategically enhance the organisation’s performance and meet consumer 
needs.

Name: Introduction to Digital Marketing 3B
Description:
The purpose of this module is to serve as an introduction to digital marketing by 
introducing students to the various tools, techniques and skills required to prepare 
students for the role that digital marketing plays within the marketing function. Students 
will gain knowledge about the digital marketing fundamentals, the platforms, channels, 
metrics and the use of the digital marketing mix elements to enhance an organisation’s 
performance and satisfy customer needs.

Name: Retailing 1A
Description:
The purpose of this module is to equip students with the necessary knowledge, that is 
needed to understand the world of retailing and the retailing environment. Students will 
also gain insight into retail buyer behaviour. On a practical level, students will be able to 
identify trends impacting the retail sector.

Name: Retailing 1B
Description:
The purpose of this module is to equip students with the necessary knowledge, insight 
for managers of a retail business. On a practical level, students will be able to explain 
the business functions relating to managing a retail business.

Name: Retailing 2A
Description:
The purpose of this module is to introduce the student to the basic principles
of marketing, mainly in a consumer product and retail context.

Name: Retailing 2B
Description:
The purpose of this module is to introduce the students to the implementation of
the marketing mix strategies, mainly in a consumer product and retail context.

Name: Practical Retailing 3B
Description:
The purpose of this module is to prepare the student to for work within the retail
environment. This module focuses on developing practical skills and competencies to
improve workplace readiness in retail businesses.

Name: Credit control 1B
Description:
The purpose of this learning guide is to introduce students to the fundamentals of credit 
concepts and challenges. On completion of this module, students able to understand the 
basic principles and processes involved in granting of or dealing with credit as it relates 
to corporates, clubs, associations, or trusts and as such able to assess and analyse the 
credit application and documentation, collect debtors, and monitor the credit risk. 
Students expected to acquire some understanding of the National Credit Act of 2005. No 
examination on the Act. It is of critical importance that students continually refer to the 
learning guide throughout the semester.

Name: Anthropology
Description: Introduction to Anthropology: Basic concepts and methodologies in anthropology.  Cultural Anthropology: Study of cultural practices, beliefs, and institutions.  Biological Anthropology: Examination of human biological diversity and evolution. Archaeology: Analysis of past human societies through material remains.  Ethnographic Methods: Training in ethnographic research techniques and fieldwork.

Name: Politics
Description: Introduction to Political Science: Overview of political theories, ideologies, andinstitutions. Comparative Politics: Analysis of different political systems and governments.  International Relations: Study of global politics, international conflicts, and cooperation.  Public Policy: Examination of policy-making processes and implementation.       Political Theory: Exploration of classical and contemporary political thought.

Name: Communication and Media Studies
Description: Introduction to Communication Studies: Basic principles and theories of communication.  Media Studies: Analysis of media content, media effects, and media industries.  Intercultural Communication: Understanding communication across different cultures and contexts.  Digital Media: Examination of digital communication technologies and their impact.  Public Relations: Study of public relations theories and practices.

Name: Psychology
Description: Introduction to Psychology: Basic concepts and principles of psychology, history of psychology, major psychological theories.  Developmental Psychology: Study of human growth and development across thelifespan. Abnormal Psychology: Examination of abnormal behavior, mental disorders, and therapeutic techniques. Cognitive Psychology: Focus on mental processes such as perception, memory, and problem-solving.  Social Psychology: Understanding how individuals are influenced by social interactions and societal factors.

Name: Development Studies
Description: Introduction to Development Studies: Overview of development theories and practices. Economic Development: Examination of economic growth, poverty, and inequality. Sustainable Development: Focus on environmental sustainability and policy-making. Globalization and Development: Impact of globalization on developing countries.  Community Development: Strategies and practices for grassroots development and  empowerment.

The primary purpose of this module is to build on your previous knowledge, understanding and
practical skills of chemistry as required for further modules in Bio and Food Technology.

Name: ENGINEERING ECONOMICS & PRACTICE 2B
Description:
To enable the student to integrate various aspects and 
perspectives of environmental management by indicating the 
importance and necessity of incorporating evaluation and 
assessment skills and tools into the field of environmental 
management.  The importance of this is viewed against the 
background of the development of small and large development 
projects as well as projects associated with engineering and the 
built environment.  Integrated environmental management, 
environmental impact assessment (EIA, social impact assessment 
(SIA) and environmental monitoring and mitigation will be used to 
identify the development of environmental problems and impacts 
which need to be mitigated or rehabilitated. It will also be illustrated 
and explained how these above mentioned skills and techniques 
can be used to overcome the ultimate problem of environmental 
degradation. Furtherm ore the module is designed to develop 
academic skills such as reading, presentation and report writing  
Content  Environmental impact assessment: Principles and practice of 
integrated environmental management, legal framework, case 
studies.

Name: Chemistry 1XA1
Description:
The primary purpose of this module is to develop the basic knowledge, understadning and practical skills of
chemical principle and techniques of general chemistr as required for further modules in Analytical
Chemistry, Bio-, and Food Technology.

Name: Biochemistry 2
Description: The module aims at introducing students to the general principles of biochemistry with emphasis on the major classes of biological molecules. Practical application is emphasised and the student must demonstrate understanding of biochemical principles by performing procedures and operating equipment in a basic  biochemistry laboratory.

Name: Intermediate Auditing
Description:
The purpose of this is to introduce students to business activities and controls in the business environment and address the method and
principles for auditing each business cycle. Detail focus is placed on risks, internal controls and audit procedures applicable to a
businesss cycles. The module also includes the relevant International Standards on Auditing (ISAs) to equip the student to apply these
during each stage in the external audit process. In addition, the module develops a wide array of non-technical skills as required by the
South African Institute of Chartered Accountants.
This module also covers risk management, the steps in completing the audit, audit reporting, auditing in an information technology
environment, and the statutory requirements of the Companies Act and business ethics.

Name: Intermediate Financial Accounting
Description:
The purpose of this module is for students to develop intellectual skills to account for practical and integrated case studies, as well as
prepare and present comprehensive financial statements to fully comply with the requirements of the International Financial Reporting
Standards with regards to intermediate to advanced routine transactions and intermediate non-routine transactions. Students should
also develop a basic awareness of the accounting issues relating to specialised reporting.

Name: Intermediate Managerial Accounting and Finance
Description:
The purpose of this section of the module is to provide students with the Competency, on an intermediate level, to understand and apply
the underlying concepts of cost accounting, i.e. the concept of advanced manufacturing environment and management accounting
techniques. Detailed knowledge regarding the concepts of stock control, planning and stock management, budgeting, standard costing,
performance measurement, transfer pricing and business strategy will be obtained.

Name: Intermediate Taxation and Tax Planning
Description:
The purpose of this module is to build on the basic concepts and ground rules regarding Income Tax as well as Value-Added Tax (VAT)
which were introduced in previous modules. It deals with more complex issues of the taxation calculation that was introduced in previous
modules. This module is to ground the student in the basic concepts and rules regarding income tax as well as Value-Added Tax (VAT). It
also deals with more complex issues of the taxation calculation.
